name: NewYorker
text:
Robin DiAngelo’s 2018 book “White Fragility” argues that our segregated society is set up to insulate whites from racial discomfort, so that they fall to pieces at the first application of stress.
https://t.co/nHHxzFhdqR

name: NewYorker
text: “In Iceland it has been run entirely by the public-health authorities,” one neurologist said, of the country’s coronavirus response. “We were fortunate that our politicians managed to control themselves.” https://t.co/x727CSG1rK

name: NewYorker
text: How Shakespeare dealt with despots, in art and in life. https://t.co/7W4wZ498o4

name: NewYorker
text: In her new photo series, “Behind Glass,” Lisa Sorgini seeks to honor mothers and their children; the title refers not only to isolation but also to Sorgini’s wish to elevate her subjects, to place them on a pedestal. https://t.co/Gt7adctQ2T

name: NewYorker
text: "There’s no way restaurants are going to be able to open and maintain the staffing levels they had before COVID," the chef and TV personality Tom Colicchio says. What will it take to keep restaurants afloat, not just through the shutdown, but after it? https://t.co/TU2SszxG1M

text:

name: NewYorker
text: In several cases that will come before the Supreme Court in the coming months, the public’s ability to seek accountability for misconduct is at stake. But, more important, the cases represent a gut check for our system of separation of powers. https://t.co/Zx07GWHyZs

name: NewYorker
text: Lauren Collins writes about her father, whose death was complicated by the coronavirus, but not caused by it. “Losing someone you love in the midst of a pandemic that has taken more than 200,000 lives is a great lesson in proportion.” https://t.co/caXbkGsZWO

name: NewYorker
text: “I think we now have a President with some of the same ideals,” a member of the Loyal White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan said, in 2016. https://t.co/D8DUJ1b8FJ

name: NewYorker
text: "I am worried about lonely educators and lonely politicians, lonely writers and lonely economists, lonely architects and lonely filmmakers, lonely organizers and lonely artists, and all the other lonely people whose job it is to imagine the future." https://t.co/ycNI0M9ADj

name: NewYorker
text: In Curtis Sittenfeld’s new novel, Hillary Rodham breaks up with Bill Clinton after law school and enters the 2016 election unencumbered by all the baggage that the Clintons accrued over four decades in politics. https://t.co/Gugf1Sa8O8

name: NewYorker
text: A new play taking place entirely on Zoom features a cast of characters popping up onscreen in video-chat squares to discuss complicated family dynamics. https://t.co/6PYmZnb8zt

name: NewYorker
text: Unicorn Riot’s coverage of the protests in Minneapolis is impressive for its intimacy with the community and unrivalled in its ability to tell the story patiently, in hour upon hour of searching the streets for clarity. https://t.co/3o2VgvkaU0

name: NewYorker
text: James Baldwin’s book about the Atlanta child murders is less about the deaths of black children than it is about their lives—about the violence and neglect that too often afflict them. https://t.co/iYktK8MmpT
